section.title: The Dashboard application
section.para: The Dashboard is a web application that allows you to view test results from within a browser. You can only see test results which are still in the database (). If you still wish to see test results after a database migration, then you should ensure that the old database instance and a Dashboard in the correct version remain installed so that older test results can be read.

section.title: The Dashboard server
section.para: In the installation directory, in the folder dashboard, you will find the dashboardserver.
When this server is started, it receives configuration information for the database you will be connected to via the browser.

For information on starting the server, refer to the later . The Dashboard can also be started with default parameters and with automatic browser opening. See the section on using the Dashboard locally for more information

The workspace directory for the Dashboard is in your home directory under:
.guidancer/dashboardWorkspace

section.title: Starting the Dashboard application in the browser
section.para: Once the Dashboard server has been started, you can start the Dashboard application in the browser. This happens automatically if you are using the dashboard application (), or you can enter a URL to start the web application and connect to the server you started ().

section.title: Using the Dashboard locally: Starting the Dashboard with default parameters and automatic browser opening
section.para: Although the Dashboard is primarily intended to be started on a central machine with access to a central database in which the test results reside, it is also possible to start the Dashboard in a default configuration to allow access to the embedded database. This option is useful if you are evaluating the function and want to use the Dashboard on your local machine without having to enter any configuration information.

listitem.para: In the installation directory, open the dashboard folder.
In this folder, start the dashboard application (Windows users use dashboard.exe, Unix users use dashboard.sh.

Starting this application starts the dashboardserver with default parameters for the embedded database. You can see which parameters are used by looking in the dashboardserver.properties file which is in the same folder as the Dashboard application.
While the server is starting, you will see a progress window. A system tray icon for the Dashboard server will appear on your screen.

Once the server is started, a browser opens containing the Reporting Perspective in which you can view and open Test Result Reports from the database ().
Bear in mind that if you are not using the embedded database, then you will have to start the Dashboard server with other parameters to connect to the database you are using ().

section.title: Using the Dashboard over the network: Starting the Dashboard server with custom parameters
section.para: You can start the Dashboard server with default parameters or with custom parameters.

listitem.para: In the installation directory, open the dashboard folder.
In this folder, start the dashboardserver.

If you start the server without any arguments, it will use the properties file dashboardserver.properties from its current working directory. You can see this properties file in the same folder as the dashboardserver on Windows and Linux, and in the folder:
dashboard/dashboardserver.app/Contents/MacOS
on Mac systems.

You can, alternatively, specify a different properties file using -c <PROPERTIES_FILE>. Keep in mind that on Mac systems you cannot use a variable (e.g.$HOME) after --args in the path of the properties file when you try to start the dashboardserver from the command line via the open command.
The properties file must contain the following properties with the values you require for them (do not use line breaks within the properties in the properties file):
listitem.programlisting:
org.eclipse.jubula.dashboard. port=<PORTNUMBER>
org.eclipse.jubula.dashboard. jdbc_driver=<JDBC_DRIVER>
org.eclipse.jubula.dashboard. jdbc_url=<JDBC_URL>
org.eclipse.jubula.dashboard. database_username=<DB_USERNAME>
org.eclipse.jubula.dashboard. database_password=<DB_PASSWORD>

listitem.para: Once the Dashboard server has started, users will be able to connect to it via the web application ().

section.title: Connecting to the Dashboard in the browser
section.para: Once a Dashboard server has been started (), then you can start the web application in the browser.
Once the application has loaded, you will see the Reporting Perspective and can use it to view and analyze test results ().

section.title: Using the Dashboard
section.para: Once you have started the Dashboard application in your browser (), you will see the Reporting Perspective you are familiar with from the ITE ().

section.title: Features available in the Dashboard
section.para: Many of the features available for viewing test results in the ITE are also available here:

listitem.para: You can reopen the Test Result View for a test run whose details are still in the database ().
You can refresh the Test Result Summary View ().
You can filter and sort in the Test Result Summary View ().
When a test result is open, you can jump to the next or previous error () and view properties details / any screenshots taken for a selected node.
You can export test results as HTML and XML reports from the Dashboard.
You cannot perform any actions in the Dashboard that alter the data in the database, e.g. deleting test result summaries, entering comments, toggling relevance or reporting to ALM.

You also cannot change the preferences via the workspace, so the default period of time for which you see test result summaries is 30 days, and the label decoration for execution duration time and parameter values are displayed ().
Code coverage reports cannot be opened in the Dashboard. You can, however, see the code coverage values in the Test Result Summary View.

section.title: Stopping the Dashboard
section.para: You can close the browser to stop viewing the Dashboard at any time. This does not, however, stop the Dashboard server.
If you are using the Dashboard application () you can stop the Dashboard server by right-clicking on the system tray icon and selecting ”Exit”.
If you started the Dashboard server (), then you can stop the Dashboard server by killing the process.
